the third cyclic run, which confirmed carbon species were not deposited over NiO-In 2 O 3 TiO 2 catalyst.This also revealed that nickel metal resists coke production.On the other hand, significant coke production was seen over Cu-InTiO 2 catalysts during CO 2 reduction with H 2 in a monolith photoreactor as reported previously 33.Using Cu-InTiO 2 , the yield of CO decreased in every cyclic runs, but productions of hydrocarbons were significantly increased.These results confirmed that nickel provides more

in the presence of NiO-In 2 O 3 co-doped TiO 2 monolithic catalysts.Fig. 11 illustrates the simple mechanism of CO 2 photoreduction with H 2 over NiO-In 2 O 3 TiO 2 supported over monolith micro-channels.When light strikes over the TiO 2 surface, electron-hole are photo-generated to initiate a photocatalytic reaction.The electrons migrate to the NiO and In 2 O 3 cluster, while holes spread on the TiO 2 surface.H 2 molecule is dissociated to H ions while CO 2 is reduced to CO and hydrocarbons by accepting

Please find the category of Light_source and Lamp from the provided context which describe an solar chemical experiment.
The generation condition of the extraction is given: If Light_source is Solar or Solar Simulator, Lamp is always Solar Simulator.

Possible Choices:

evidence.pdf_reference: stainless steel chamber with 5.5 cm length and a total volume of 150 cm 3 as previously described 8.The catalyst-coated monolith was placed inside the cylindrical stainless steel chamber with a quartz window for passing light irradiations.The light source for UV irradiation was a 200 W Hg reflector lamp.The lamp was equipped with cooling fans to remove heat from the lamp.The straight square cordierite monolith channels were illuminated with the flux of the reflected light source.An optical process monitor

optical process monitor ILT OPM-1D and a SED008 W sensor were placed above the upper surface of the monolith to measure the light intensity entering into the channels.The total light influx passing at the top of the reactor was measured to be 150 mW cm A2 .The reactor was covered with aluminum foil to ensure lights for the reactions came through the quartz window only.In case of the cell type photoreactor, the reactor chamber and the light source were the same as that of the monolith reactor.However, 50 mg

blank runs were conducted to correct the base line.The absorbance spectra were analyzed at ambient temperature in the wavelength range of 200-800 nm.The band gap energies of the photocatalysts were determined from the extrapolation of Tauc plot to the abscissa of photon energy.The photoluminescence (PL) spectra were measured using PerkinElmer LS 55 Luminescence Spectrometer. evidence.pdf_reference: at a feed rate of 20 mLmin and the products were continuously analyzed over the entire irradiation time. A minimum reaction temperature of 100 C was selected for catalyst screening in the RWGS reaction.The effect of reaction temperatures (100, 120 and 140 C) was investigated for determining if the process was thermal, photo-thermal or photocatalysis.The temperature inside the reactor was controlled with a temperature controller. blank runs were conducted to correct the base line.The absorbance spectra were analyzed at ambient temperature in the wavelength range of 200-800 nm.The band gap energies of the photocatalysts were determined from the extrapolation of Tauc plot to the abscissa of photon energy.The photoluminescence (PL) spectra were measured using PerkinElmer LS 55 Luminescence Spectrometer. monolith reactor.However, 50 mg of catalyst powder was suspended uniformly at the bottom of the reactor to ensure light is distributed over the catalyst surface. Before feeding, the reactor was purged with helium (He).A mixture of gases (CO 2 , H 2 and He, purity 99.99) was passed through the reactor for a specific time to saturate the catalysts at room temperature and atmospheric pressure.The performance of NiO-In 2 O 3 TiO 2 monolith photoreactor was investigated in a batch and continuous mode.In a batch

and continuous mode.In a batch mode operation of monolith photoreactor, H 2 concentration was fixed at 20 mol, while CO 2 concentrations of 10, 20, 30 and 40 mol were used to control the CO 2 H 2 ratios at 0.5, 1.0, 1.5 and 2.0, respectively.He gas was used to culminate the mole balance to 100 mol.The pressure inside the reactor was set to 0.40 bar using a pressure controller for batch mode study.In a continuous monolith photoreactor, the CO 2 H 2 ratio of 1.0 was adjusted at a feed rate of 20 mLmin and

evidence.pdf_reference: monolith reactor.However, 50 mg of catalyst powder was suspended uniformly at the bottom of the reactor to ensure light is distributed over the catalyst surface. Before feeding, the reactor was purged with helium (He).A mixture of gases (CO 2 , H 2 and He, purity 99.99) was passed through the reactor for a specific time to saturate the catalysts at room temperature and atmospheric pressure.The performance of NiO-In 2 O 3 TiO 2 monolith photoreactor was investigated in a batch and continuous mode.In a batch

type photoreactor revealed a 14.13-fold higher productivity in the batch monolith photoreactor than the cell type reactor under the identical reaction conditions.Significantly higher efficiency of monolith photoreactor was primarily due to a larger illuminated surface area, efficient light distribution and utilization over the NiO-In 2 O 3 TiO 2 catalyst surface and enhanced adsorption-desorption process 31.On the other hand, the performance of the batch monolith photoreactor is 1.90-fold higher than

monolith batch process and monolith continuous process, respectively.These results revealed higher performance of both batch and continuous monolith photoreactor than the cell type reactor.The improved efficiency was obviously due to hindered recombination of charges in the presence of NiO and In 2 O 3 co-doped ions into TiO 2 . The quantum efficiency increased using H 2 as the reducing agent compared to water vapours.We reported quantum efficiency of 0.10 for CO production over In 2 O 3 TiO 2 catalyst
